H0.text: The motion of the ball causes it to slow down and then stop when a student rolls it on the ground.

H1.text: The speed of the ball causes it to slow down and then stop when a student rolls the ball on the ground.

H2.text: Friction from the ground causes the ball to slow down and then stop when a student rolls it on the ground.

H3.text: A magnetic field causes a ball rolled on the ground by a student to slow down and then stop.

A4.text: An example of static friction is the force that prevents a car wheel from slipping as it rolls on the ground.

A5.text: Rolling resistance is the force that resists the rolling of a wheel or other circular object along a surface caused by deformations in the object or surface.
